trans-unit.source: Creating Tables with Different Schedules
trans-unit.target: Creating Tables with Different Schedules

trans-unit.source: Creating Tables with Different Schedules
trans-unit.target: Creating Tables with Different Schedules

trans-unit.source: This topic provides the JSON format that is supported by the July 2015 Release of PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides the JSON format that is supported by the July 2015 Release of PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: If you are using an older version, see <link xlink:href="dffee8b2-deec-41ab-9664-a854d81263e5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Creating Tables with Different Schedules</link> for the old JSON format.
trans-unit.target: If you are using an older version, see <link xlink:href="dffee8b2-deec-41ab-9664-a854d81263e5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Creating Tables with Different Schedules</link> for the old JSON format.

trans-unit.source: This topics covers the following two scenarios:
trans-unit.target: This topics covers the following two scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Input table with a weekly schedule and output table with a daily schedule
trans-unit.target: Input table with a weekly schedule and output table with a daily schedule

trans-unit.source: While creating Azure Data Factory pipelines, you can have different schedules (hourly, daily, weekly, and monthly, etc…)
trans-unit.target: While creating Azure Data Factory pipelines, you can have different schedules (hourly, daily, weekly, and monthly, etc…)

trans-unit.source: on input and output tables.
trans-unit.target: on input and output tables.

trans-unit.source: One of the scenarios is to have input tables available weekly and output tables produced daily.
trans-unit.target: One of the scenarios is to have input tables available weekly and output tables produced daily.

trans-unit.source: The slicing mechanism in Azure Data Factory makes it very easy to depend on a weekly dataset.
trans-unit.target: The slicing mechanism in Azure Data Factory makes it very easy to depend on a weekly dataset.

trans-unit.source: You can depend on a day in the past week because input slices are weekly and the dependency condition would be met when the past week’s data is ready.
trans-unit.target: You can depend on a day in the past week because input slices are weekly and the dependency condition would be met when the past week’s data is ready.

trans-unit.source: Here is how you can configure your input tables in Azure Data Factory for this scenario:
trans-unit.target: Here is how you can configure your input tables in Azure Data Factory for this scenario:

trans-unit.source: OR
trans-unit.target: OR

trans-unit.source: See <link xlink:href="ce76160a-90f2-4459-950a-34c43d8c919b" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Factory Functions</link> topic for details about functions (AddWeeks etc…)
trans-unit.target: See <link xlink:href="ce76160a-90f2-4459-950a-34c43d8c919b" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Factory Functions</link> topic for details about functions (AddWeeks etc…)

trans-unit.source: used in this section.
trans-unit.target: used in this section.

trans-unit.source: Input with an arbitrary schedule
trans-unit.target: Input with an arbitrary schedule

trans-unit.source: You can also have your input table produced on an arbitrary schedule and output tables being produced daily.
trans-unit.target: You can also have your input table produced on an arbitrary schedule and output tables being produced daily.

trans-unit.source: A general solution regardless of the input schedule is to calculate the slice that corresponds to the past week.
trans-unit.target: A general solution regardless of the input schedule is to calculate the slice that corresponds to the past week.

trans-unit.source: Here is how you can configure your input tables for this case:
trans-unit.target: Here is how you can configure your input tables for this case:

trans-unit.source: Or (for a daily/hourly/minute output schedule)
trans-unit.target: Or (for a daily/hourly/minute output schedule)
